speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first started feeling unwell? Was it sudden or did it come on gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: "I think it was a bit of both, to be honest. One day I just didn't feel like playing with my toys, and then my legs started to feel a bit... tight, I guess. My parents said I've been breathing pretty fast for a few days now."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly where on your body the tightness is?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's just on my legs, I think. My knees and calves, especially. It's hard to explain, but it feels like someone is squeezing them a little bit."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the tightness you're experiencing in your legs? Does it feel like it's getting worse or staying the same?

speaker: Patient
text: "Hmm, it's been a bit hard to tell, but I think it might be getting a little bit worse. My legs feel a bit heavier, and it's harder to move around. I have to stop and catch my breath a lot, even when I'm just playing."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities? Are you able to run around and play with your friends like you normally do, or do you have to slow down a lot?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really like to run around as much as I used to. I have to stop and catch my breath a lot, so I don't play with my friends as much as I want to. Sometimes I get really tired just playing with blocks or coloring, and I have to sit down and rest for a bit."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your appetite? Have you noticed any changes in how hungry you are or if you're able to eat as much as you used to? Also, I'd like to take a look at your abdomen. Can you show me where your liver is, and is it swollen or tender to the touch?

speaker: Patient
text: "My appetite has been... smaller, I guess. I don't really feel like eating as much as I used to. Sometimes I just want to have a small snack and then I'm full, instead of wanting a big meal like I used to."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly where on your abdomen the liver is? Is it swollen or tender to the touch?

speaker: Patient
text: "Uh, I think the liver is... on my right side, I think. It's hard to remember, but my mom always says it's on the right side. And, um, I don't feel anything weird about it, I don't think. It feels kind of... firm, I guess, but not really painful or anything."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities, and if you've noticed any changes in your energy levels or overall feeling of well-being? Also, REQUEST TEST: Liver Ultrasound

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns? Do you often wake up in the middle of the night feeling short of breath or do you have trouble falling asleep?

speaker: Patient
text: "Hmm, I don't really remember waking up in the middle of the night feeling short of breath, but I do feel really tired all the time. Sometimes I just want to sleep and sleep, and when I do, I usually sleep really soundly, but then I wake up feeling really tired again."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the types of activities that make you feel short of breath? For example, is it just playing, or do you feel short of breath when you're doing everyday things like walking or even just sitting still?

speaker: Patient
text: "Oh, yeah... I feel short of breath when I'm doing just about anything, I think. Like, when I'm playing with blocks, or coloring, or even just sitting on the couch. I have to stop and catch my breath a lot, and it's hard to get going again. Even just walking from one room to another makes me feel really tired and short of breath."

speaker: Doctor

I have to stop and catch my breath a lot, and it's hard to get going again. Even just walking from one room to another makes me feel really tired and short of breath." Can you describe to me what happens when you're feeling short of breath? Do you feel like you're going to pass out, or is it more of a tightness in your chest? "I don't really feel like I'm going to pass out, but it's like my chest is really tight and it hurts. And it makes it hard to breathe, like I have to work really hard to catch my breath. Sometimes I feel like I'm going to get really dizzy and fall over."

speaker: Patient
text: "Sometimes I feel really dizzy and fall over when I'm standing up too fast or when I'm playing too hard. It's like my legs aren't working right and I feel like I'm going to fall over."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first noticed that your legs weren't working right? Was it after you started feeling short of breath, or did it come on before that? And can you show me exactly where on your legs you feel like they're not working right? Is it just in the knees and calves like you mentioned earlier?

speaker: Patient
text: "I think it was a bit of both, to be honest. One day I just didn't feel like playing with my toys, and then my legs started to feel a bit... tight, I guess. My parents said I've been breathing pretty fast for a few days now."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly where on your legs you feel like they're not working right? Is it just in the knees and calves like you mentioned earlier? And can you tell me more about what happens when you're standing up from a lying down position? Do you feel dizzy or lightheaded?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's just in my knees and calves, like I said before. And, um, yeah... when I'm standing up from a lying down position, I feel a bit dizzy and lightheaded, like my legs are going to give out on me. It's hard to explain, but it's like my body is telling me to sit down and rest, even when I don't want to."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensations you experience when you're feeling dizzy and lightheaded? Does it feel like your room is spinning, or is it more of a feeling of being unsteady on your feet?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's like my room is spinning a bit, I guess. It's hard to describe, but it feels like everything is moving around me and I'm not really sure what's going on. It's not really like I'm feeling unsteady on my feet, it's more like... my whole body is wobbly, I think."
